Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Theories and experiments on scalar mixing in chaotic flows
Award.AbstractNarration:
Tang
DMS-1212144
Ouellette
DMS-1211952

The investigators model and quantify scalar diffusion in the limit where homogenization theory is invalid. This regime is typical when the scalar in the flow has sources or sinks due to physical or biological forces, such as release or mitigation of contaminants, birth and death processes, predator-prey interactions in biological species, or many others. As a result, the classical assumptions of turbulent isotropy and homogeneity do not apply, and the mathematical challenge is to properly represent enhanced diffusion (from molecular motion) by the associated fluid motion at scales smaller or comparable to the characteristic forcing scale of the flow. The complementary expertise of the investigators enables the development of mathematically based models that are verified with numerical and physical experiments. The investigators study scalar mixing from a variety of angles. Topological measures on the background stirring, based on dynamical systems methods, are used and tested for modeling turbulent diffusion with coherent structures. Additionally, mixing measures associated with sources and sinks are studied with an upper bound approach. Overall, the investigators study how mathematical theory can be used and adapted to explain inhomogeneous, anisotropic diffusion processes observable from physical experiments.

Transport and mixing processes associated with pollutants, such as the Gulf oil spill and radioactive contamination in Japan, and with biological tracers, such as plankton blooms, are greatly affected by stirring patterns in the background flow. The novel theoretical and experimental studies proposed here lay the foundation for improved mathematical models and simulations of scalar mixing for many environmental and geophysical processes; in particular, they can be used to address realistic environmental problems. Other broad impacts include training of a graduate student and a postdoctoral researcher. Moreover, the experiments and visualizations from simulations, along with some analytical and computational tools used in this research, are blended into the investigators' outreach efforts to engage high school students' interest in mathematics and physics. The project is supported by the Division of Chemical, Bioengineering, Environmental, and Transport Systems and by the Division of Mathematical Sciences.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The PI and his group have completed research on scalar transport and mixing problems in chaotic flows supported by the grant from NSF Division of Mathematical Sciences. During the grant period, one PhD student, one M.Sc student and three undergraduate students have received training on analytical and numerical skills for solving differential equations describing the relevant physical problems. The students are trained on parallel programming skills using super computers. They also received opportunities to present their guided studies at national and international conferences. One PhD dissertation (pending completion) and one Master's thesis, as well as several peer reviewed journal papers, are based on research outcomes from the grant. Two of the undergraduate students received NSF graduate fellowships.


Research activities associated with the project have been on developing mathematical tools to study the diffusion and reaction of substances in the natural environment in regimes not well explored previously --- complex flows where there are long-lasting coherent eddies, and with small-scale sources such as the gushing oil spill or leaked radioactive substances from localized sites. This scenario of small-scale sources in large-scale environmental flows bring distinct mixing characteristics as compared to traditional studies. The sources could be of physical, biological or chemical origin.


By considering diffusion of substances without sources, hence the free spread of the concentrations, it was first found that the dispersion characteristics are coherent, if one employs mathematical tools from nonlinear dynamics that describes behaviors of non-diffusive paths and separate the environmental flows into coherent eddies and chaotic mixtures. In fact, it is also found that the diffusion characteristics can be sensitive to how one separates the flow into these different regions. Then, by utilizing tools from mathematical analyses, together with approximations of the flow based on averaged behaviors of fluid paths, a new model has been developed to study this mixing problem. The model is mathematically exact for the approximations, and complex behaviors associated with the chaotic flows are captured when one iteratively apply the approximation methods.

By considering compact sources that are of chemical (biological) nature, through careful analyses of the different types of chemical reactions, the role of stretching along fluid paths in each individual reaction processes is found. Generally speaking, when the activity happens in transient time and on small length scales (which is the regime of interest here), the reaction processes are highly dependent on the stretching amount and history along the paths. However, exactly what and how a chemical quantity is influenced by stretching is dependent on the individual reactions. For example, high stretching (associated with different features of the flow) can help chemicals react faster to spread in the environment, but in certain reaction problems it can also suppress the reaction. These differences help quantify the uncertainty of the reaction processes, which could be quantitatively (such as the amount of bioproductivity) or qualitatively (such as if phytoplankton is in and out of an outbreak)  different depending on just the flow features.


As such, the fundamental connections between paths from the chaotic flows, and diffusion and reaction processes that are carried by the flow, have been established. New aspects of diffusion and reaction have thus been discovered and modeled (explained) through proper extension of various mathematical tools developed in other studies.
